metadata.description: Full-text search index for display technology documentation

documents.title: Liquid Crystal Display Technology
documents.content: Liquid crystal displays LCD use liquid crystals to control light transmission from a backlight. Active matrix displays use thin film transistors TFT for precise pixel control. Color filters create RGB subpixels. Viewing angles and response times vary by liquid crystal mode.

documents.title: Organic Light Emitting Diode Displays
documents.content: OLED displays are self-emissive using organic compounds that emit light when current is applied. No backlight needed. Perfect blacks and infinite contrast ratio. Susceptible to burn-in and moisture damage. Active matrix AMOLED uses TFT backplane.

documents.title: Micro LED Display Technology
documents.content: Micro LED uses microscopic inorganic LEDs as pixels. Self-emissive like OLED but more durable. Extremely high brightness and efficiency. Modular design enables seamless tiling. Manufacturing challenges include mass transfer and uniformity control.

documents.title: Quantum Dot Color Enhancement
documents.content: Quantum dots are semiconductor nanocrystals that emit pure colors when excited by light. Used in backlights or as photoluminescent layers. Dramatically improves color gamut coverage. Can achieve over 100% DCI-P3 and approach Rec 2020 standards.

documents.title: Display Backlight Technologies
documents.content: Backlights provide illumination for transmissive displays. Edge-lit uses LEDs on panel edges with light guide. Direct-lit places LEDs behind entire panel. Full-array local dimming enables HDR. Quantum dot backlights improve color purity.

documents.title: Thin Film Transistor Technology
documents.content: TFT switches control individual pixels in active matrix displays. Amorphous silicon a-Si is common but has mobility limitations. Low temperature polysilicon LTPS offers better performance. IGZO and oxide TFTs enable larger displays and higher resolution.

documents.title: Color Filter Array Design
documents.content: Color filters selectively transmit red green blue wavelengths to create color pixels. RGB stripe is common layout. PenTile uses fewer green subpixels. RGBW adds white subpixel for brightness. Quantum dot color filters eliminate need for backlights.

documents.title: Display Photolithography Manufacturing
documents.content: Photolithography patterns features on display substrates using ultraviolet light and photoresist. Critical for TFT fabrication and color filter formation. Resolution determines minimum feature size. Alignment accuracy affects yield. Multi-layer process builds complex structures.

documents.title: Display Encapsulation Methods
documents.content: Encapsulation protects sensitive display components from moisture and oxygen. OLED especially vulnerable. Glass frit sealing provides excellent barrier. Thin film encapsulation uses alternating barrier layers. Hybrid approaches combine both methods for flexibility.

documents.title: Display Substrate Materials
documents.content: Glass substrates provide rigid base for display manufacturing. Soda lime glass is economical. Borosilicate offers better thermal stability. Polyimide enables flexible displays. Steel foil substrates allow roll-to-roll processing. Surface treatment critical for adhesion.

documents.title: Transparent Conductive Materials
documents.content: Transparent conductors enable electrical contact while maintaining optical clarity. Indium tin oxide ITO is standard but brittle and expensive. Silver nanowire offers flexibility. Graphene shows promise but immature. Metal mesh provides low resistance.

documents.title: Display Brightness and Luminance
documents.content: Brightness measures light output in candela per square meter or nits. Typical displays range 100-400 nits. HDR requires 1000+ nits peak brightness. Outdoor displays need 1500+ nits. OLED can achieve very high peak but limited sustained brightness due to heat.

documents.title: Display Contrast Ratio Performance
documents.content: Contrast ratio compares brightest white to darkest black. LCD limited by backlight leakage, typically 1000:1 native. Local dimming improves contrast. OLED achieves perfect blacks for infinite contrast. Ambient light reduces perceived contrast significantly.

documents.title: Display Color Gamut Coverage
documents.content: Color gamut defines reproducible color range. sRGB standard for web content. Adobe RGB for photography. DCI-P3 for cinema and HDR. Rec 2020 for future broadcast. Quantum dots and wide gamut backlights approach these standards.

documents.title: Display Response Time and Motion
documents.content: Response time measures pixel transition speed. Gray-to-gray commonly specified. LCD limited by liquid crystal switching, 1-5ms typical. OLED achieves sub-millisecond response. Gaming monitors prioritize fast response. Overdrive reduces response time but may cause overshoot.
